environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) Meylan WM, Howard PH; J Pharm Sci 84: 83-92 (1995) (2) Meylan WM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 18: 664-72 (1999) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: An estimated BCF of 9 was calculated for cresyl glycidyl ether(SRC), using an estimated log Kow of 2.2(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Chemicals Inspection and Testing Institute; Japan Chemical Industry Ecology - Toxicology and Information Center. ISBN 4-89074-101-1 (1992)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: Biodegradation data for cresyl glycidyl ether were not available(SRC, 2006). However, a 33% theoretical BOD using the Japanese MITI test for analogous phenyl glycidyl ether(1) suggests that biodegradation of cresyl glycidyl ether may occur in aquatic environments(SRC).

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Undiluted o-Cresyl glycidyl ether produced severe skin irritation at 24 hr, which progressed to necrosis by 14 days. Following a 4-hr semioccluded exposure o-cresyl glycidyl ether caused slight irritation to the skin with a complete recovery of the irritant effects within 7 days. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Signs of /acute oral/ toxicity /in rats/ included dyspnea and lacrimation, and congested liver was observed at necropsy ...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Signs of intoxication /in rats/ were ataxia and general depression. Dermal exposure resulted in severe dermal irritation. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ /Cresyl glycidyl ether/ is a moderate skin irritant in rabbits ...

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Cresyl glycidyl ether is a potent skin sensitizer in guinea pigs.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ In a maximization test in guinea pigs ... o-cresyl glycidyl ether caused a response in 80% of the treated animals. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ Cresyl glycidyl ether and o-cresyl glycidyl ether are slightly irritating to the rabbit eye; recovery is rapid.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Sheftel, V.O.; Indirect Food Additives and Polymers. Migration and Toxicology. Lewis Publishers, Boca Raton, FL. 2000., p. 720
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Acute Exposure/ /In acute toxicity testing in rats, mice, and guinea pigs/ manifestations of the toxic action include a short period of excitation (20-30 min) with subsequent CNS inhibition, increased respiratory rate, and adynamia. Death occurs within 8 days after administration. Gross pathology  examination revealed dystrophic and destructive changes in the parenchyma of the viscera. Liver lesions and necrosis of the renal tubular epithelium were also found.

/LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ Epoxide number 8, an epoxy-reactive diluent, was more allergenic than butyl glycidyl ether, a known skin sensitizer, as determined by the guinea pig maximization test. The potential allergenicity of epoxide number 8 indicated by positive reactions of cresyl glycidyl ether and epoxy resin in animals sensitized to epoxide number 8.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Clayton, G. D. and F. E. Clayton (eds.). Patty's Industrial Hygiene and Toxicology: Volume 2A, 2B, 2C: Toxicology. 3rd ed. New York: John Wiley Sons, 1981-1982., p. 2204
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ With rabbits, short exposure /to skin/ has no appreciable effect. Prolonged exposure results in severe hyperemia, swelling, and necrosis. Abraded skin is particularly susceptible.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ In a 4-wk (6 hr/day, 5 days/wk) study rats were exposed to vapors of o-cresyl glycidyl ether at the highest practically attainable concentration (26.9 mg/cu m, 4 ppm). There were no adverse effects observed in any of the in-life parameters, hematology, urinalysis, clinical chemistry, and macroscopic and microscopic pathology. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1069
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Subchronic or Prechronic Exposure/ Rats inhaled aerosols of o-cresyl glycidyl ether at concentrations of 0, 53, 152, or 305 mg/cu m for 3 wk (5 days/wk; 6 hr/day). There was significant mortality in the highest exposure group. Survivors and animals of the 53-mg/cu m group had significant inflammation and ulceration of the nasal passages; within 3 wk these effects had largely recovered. At all exposure levels reduced food consumption and growth, dyspnea, and exophthalmos were observed. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Sheftel, V.O.; Indirect Food Additives and Polymers. Migration and Toxicology. Lewis Publishers, Boca Raton, FL. 2000., p. 720
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /LABORATORY ANIMALS: Developmental or Reproductive Toxicity/ Following inhalation exposure, gonadotoxic and embryotoxic effects are shown to develop at concentrations lower than the general toxicity level (2.55 mg/cu m).

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1070
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ In an unscheduled DNA synthesis assay in human lymphocytes, o-cresyl glycidyl ether produced significant increases in unscheduled DNA synthesis at 10 and 100 ppm; it was cytotoxic at 1000 ppm. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1070
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ In a micronucleus assay in female B6D2F1 mice 5 daily oral doses of 125 mg/kg o-cresyl glycidyl ether did not induce an increase in micronuclei in bone marrow extracted 4 hr following the last dose. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1070
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ o-Cresyl glycidyl ether was tested for its ability to induce mutations in male transgenic mice ... Animals were exposed dermally to 5 daily doses of 500 mg/kg o-cresyl glycidyl ether. After 7 and 28 days, DNA was extracted from samples of skin- at the site of treatment- liver and bone marrow and assayed for mutations in LacZ transgenes. No increases in mutation frequency were recorded in the treated skin or in any of the distant tissues. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1070
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ o-Cresyl glycidyl ether was a direct-acting mutagen in Salmonella typhimurium strains TA 1535 and TA 100 in the Ames assay. p-Cresyl glycidyl ether was active in these strains both in the presence and absence of a rat and hamster liver S9 fraction. No activity was observed in strain TA 98. /o- and p-Cresyl glycidyl ethers/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1070
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ Cresyl glycidyl ether caused reverse mutations in strains TA 100 and TA 1535 in the absence of rat liver S9; however, a weak activity was also recorded in TA 1535 in the presence of S9. Cresyl glycidyl ether did not respond in strains TA 98, TA 1537, and TA 1538 and in Saccharomyces cerevisiae D4. The data indicate that cresyl glycidyl ether exerts its mutagenic potential by causing base-pair mutations.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1070
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ In a host-mediated assay mice were exposed orally to 4 daily doses of 125 mg/kg o-cresyl glycidyl ether; after last dose the animals were inoculated with Salmonella typhimurium TA1535. Urine of mice (ICR or B6D2F1 strain) treated similarly with o-cresyl glycidyl ether was also assayed for mutagenic activity in TA1535, either in presence or absence of beta-glucuronidase. There was no evidence of mutagenicity, with the exception of a weak response of the urine of ICR mice treated with beta-glucuronidase. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Sheftel, V.O.; Indirect Food Additives and Polymers. Migration and Toxicology. Lewis Publishers, Boca Raton, FL. 2000., p. 720
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /GENOTOXICITY/ 1,2-Epoxy-3-(tolyoxy)propane caused mutations in the microorganisms, Salmonella typhimurium and S. cerevisiae.

non_human_toxicity_excerpts.References: Bingham, E.; Cohrssen, B.; Powell, C.H.; Patty's Toxicology Volumes 1-9 5th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, N.Y. (2001)., p. 6:1070
non_human_toxicity_excerpts.Value: /ALTERNATIVE IN VITRO TESTS/ o-Cresyl glycidyl ether has been shown to form adducts with the N-terminal valine of hemoglobin following incubation with mouse and human erythrocytes or after ip injection to mice. In unexposed individuals these adducts could not be detected. /o-Cresyl glycidyl ether/

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Meylan WM et al; Environ Sci Technol 26: 1560-67 (1992) (2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(1), the Koc of cresyl glycidyl ether can be estimated to be 67(SRC). According to a classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that cresyl glycidyl ether is expected to have high mobility in soil.
